textbooks.title: Computer Architecture: A Quantitative Approach
textbooks.author: John L. Hennessy and David A. Patterson

topics: Introduction, Course Syllabus, and Introduction to computer architecture
Data Level Parallelism (DLP) and Thread Level Parallelism (TLP)

grading.policies: Assignments received 1-6 days late will have 20% of the total points deducted; assignments received more than one week late will receive 0 points.

important_dates.date: To be announced a week before the final exam

additional_info.technology_requirements: Basic computer and web-browsing skills, navigating Canvas, live web conferencing using Zoom, current Mac (OS X) or PC (Windows 7+) with high-speed internet connection, webcam, microphone, Microsoft Word, Microsoft PowerPoint.
additional_info.support_resources: For more information about course access or support, contact the Technology Resource and Assistance Center (TRAC) by calling 201-216-5500.

_metadata.course_description: This course introduces students to computer architecture and the design of efficient computing and memory systems.
learning_outcomes: Understand the quantitative approach for computer architecture design and be able to apply metrics to evaluate performance of a computer system.
Comprehend the fundamentals of digital systems and organization of an ARM processor.
Understand the basic Instruction Set Architecture (ISA) and able to design a five-stage pipeline.
Analyze computer memory systems using cache protocols, paging mechanism, and memory access time formula.
Able to use instruction, thread and data level parallelisms.
